content: Thunderbird was never designed as a backup tool, but it can do that somewhat clumsily. The default POP setup is to download and delete, and my guess is that is what you did. You can change settings to download and keep.
creator: davidsk

content: What was the account type with the old drive, and what is the account type with the new drive - POP or IMAP?
creator: christ1

content:
My first suggestion is to verify that the SMTP server is for that account. To do that, - click 'account settings' - click the account name in left sidebar - now, on bottom line in right side of screen, click the 'edit SMTP server' button - on next screen, verify that the email account is correct, and not for one of your other accounts - if it is for another account, go back to prior screen and click the drop-down menu for outgoing SMTP server and set to the right server.

The above may not be relevant, but it is a common problem when a user has multiple accounts with same provider.
creator: davidsk

content: Thank you David for your quick answer. Unfortunatly, email account is correct in SMTP server.

Thunderbird has a rich variety of font settings. I believe they are documented in this link. The options you are referencing are not the best choice.

creator: davidsk

content: I appreciate your reply, but it does not solve my issue/problem. My composition settings are set correctly, in fact they are set to the default settings (font Luciana Grande, text size 11pt), however while creating/typing the email the font that is appearing on my screen is the equivalent of 8pt font size and the only way that I can fix this is on a per email basis to go into the Zoom In menu option and increase the font size on my own screen. I cannot figure out why, or how to permanently correct/adjust the size of the font that is appearing while I am typing an email. Once I send the email and it is received by the recipient (I tested this myself on other emails that I have), the font is the correct size. If you have any other ideas/ suggestions, I would appreciate it.
creator: rkovacs

content:
please understand that thunderbird does not use points, but pixels. You need to increase the size from 11 to 15. And, from the article I gave you, set the desired font to both the latin and the other one for all fonts, including the minimum size.

Further, from the article I gave you, Thunderbird does NOT include font size in emails unless you force large or extra large or small. The font size you see on screen is for you. If sent without font size - or as plain text - the recipient's email client sets the size. That is why I recommend setting the HTML composition font to variable width, as that frees the recipient to see the font in his/her chosen font and font size.
creator: davidsk

content: Most likely you do have an email account with your ISP, but you aren't connected to the Internet via your ISP. Your ISP does require you connect through them to be able send mail through their SMTP server.

content: I suggest starting with your online account. It may be that Outlook is rejecting it. I'm not familiar with Outlook, but I do use Gmail and it sometimes rejects email with no explanation. You might try changing your address for that institution to a different email account and see what happens then. And, you might contact the institution to report the problem. such institutions to have tech staff and they may have more info for you.
